results.title: Film and you
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Donald Fraser, Jean Palardy and Donald Peters
results.brief_description: This film describes how film councils are organised, and what they can do for the community. Different people like different things - for instance, Grandpa, who goes to sleep during a sequence on kitchen planning, wakes joyfully at the sound of a square dance. But all groups agree that they want films on their programs, if they can get them, and that is where the film council comes in. Animation shows how a council is set up, and how a number of organisations in an area can collaborate in buying a projector. We see projectionist training, and the public library becoming a distribution centre for films as well as books. Finally, we see film in action, as a variety of successful community projects are carried out, each directly the result of film showings.

results.title: Film and reality
results.creator_credit: BFI, Alberto Cavalcanti and Ernest Lindgren
results.brief_description: A compilation documentary which follows the history of Realist film from the earliest days until World War II. The film is presented in five sections - early Realist film and its divorce from film drama; foundations of the Realist film; romantic documentary on “Far-Off Lands”; the Realistic Documentary of “Life at home”; Realism and the Story Film - the Feature Film. Some of the films on display are: Nanook of the North, Rien que les heures, The General Line, Drifters etc.

results.title: Filing procedures in business
results.brief_description: Shows a large efficient central filing system functioning as an integral part of a well-run business organisation. The film is designed to teach students the correct procedures to be followed in operating such a filing system.

results.title: Filbert and the melon cheater: subtraction with borrowing
results.creator_credit: Encyclopaedia Britannica Films and Davidson Films
results.brief_description: Introduces two digit subtraction problems, including those which require regrouping, through an animated story about the problems of an honest melon merchant. Filbert devises an accounting system called “dump a box” based on subtraction with borrowing to try to stop a melon thief. Suitable for upper primary level.

results.title: Figures in motion
results.creator_credit: AFTRS, Priscilla Collins and Damien Power
results.brief_description: Eadweard Muybridge was the pioneer photographer whose experiments in stop-motion photography helped develop the technology that resulted in motion pictures. In this sly and elegant short film, Muybridge forces his young wife to pose nude with his male lover. As the photographer begins to take his shots, he becomes more and more excited by the control he can exercise over both his lovers. An initially camp and light treatment of the erotics that forms the basis of voyeuristic desire in cinema, the film becomes progressively darker as Muybridge’s wife becomes the object of not only desire, but of appropriation and violence, signifying that even at the birth of cinema the male gaze was rapacious and pornographic.

results.title: Figures in a landscape
results.brief_description: The works and methods of sculpture and stone of the contemporary abstract artist Barbara Hepworth, are compared and contrasted with their natural influences in the rocks and landscape of Cornwall.

results.title: Figures in a landscape
results.creator_credit: Cinecrest, John Kohn and Joseph Losey
results.brief_description: A helicopter, hovering, swoops, wheels and searches like some malignant mechanical bat. Below two men, their hands tied behind their backs, flee for their lives. MacConnachie, played by Robert Shaw, is forty and Ansell, played by Malcolm McDowell, is in his early twenties. Ahead lies 400 miles of hostile terrain they must cross to escape. Between each other lies a deep mutual mistrust, but they are bound by a common need to escape and survive. MacConnachie moves by instinct and Ansell by reason. On and on the two men are hunted by the unrelenting helicopter, and unlike ordinary men who would keep running, they hunt back.

results.title: Figure skating
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Peter Jones and Ernest Reid
results.brief_description: An invitation to experience the thrill of spinning, jumping, skimming, and dancing on winged feet. The film shows how Canada’s champions do it. Maria and Otto Jelinek, Don Jackson, Wendy Griner and Don McPherson appear briefly in dazzling exhibition, but the main object of the film is to show that figure skating is for everyone - children, young people, and adults.
